newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: NYMEX crude still firm on mounting US/Iraq tension.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX crude still firm on mounting US/Iraq tension.

text.p: Crude prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange's (NYMEX) after-hours ACCESS trading system remained firm in Asia late Tuesday amid the escalating tensions between United States and Iraq, brokers said.
At 0904 GMT, October NYMEX crude last traded at $23.85 per barrel, a shade under its days's high of $24.00 on profit-taking.

The contract has jumped 22 cents to $23.70 at 0627 GMT in response to news that the United States had launched cruise missiles at military targets in Iraq. Brokers noted that the U.S. attacks have since stopped.
Reports quoted a western defence official in the Middle East as saying U.S. navy warships in the Gulf and B-52 bombers fired 25 to 30 cruise missiles on military targets in southern Iraq.
Washington said the attack was in retaliation for Iraqi military attacks against Kurds in the north.
